addressleaf.section: A Monsieur Monsieur de Sidney chevalier et Governeur de la Ville de Vlissingnes

page.lettertext:
fol.170r
S
r
Tho Bodley to S
r
Robert Sydney
Yo
r
L
ordships
of
e 10
th
came two daies past
unto my handes, w
t
with
e inclosed from my Lorde.
I attended no commission to perfourme
e
contents: but yet
e negligence was great,
of those
at kept it so long, before the y sent
it unto yo
w
. I have caused his Ex
cie
to
deale w
t
this
Counsell,
for
e removing of
yo
r
cornet: w
ch
they have resolved to send
to waggening, and to
at effort they have
written to
Mons
r
de Locres
e Governo
r
to
signifie their intention. Within these 3 daies
we expect his answear, whereof yow shall
have knowledge, and a patent sent unto
yo
w
. I am sorie
Cap
t
Littleton
hath
failed of his purpose, w
ch
is knowen all
abroade. The occurrences heere and
howe
S
r
John Norreis
hath spedde w
t
with
e states,
he himself will signifie, being almost
ready to depart assoone as this messenger.
And so for this present I bidde yo
r
L
ordship
farewell. From
e Hage
Marche 16
1590.
Yo
r
L
dships
at commaundem
t
Tho. Bodley
Cap
t
Samson
is newly come unto
e
Haghe, who shall want no assistance,
at
I can give, albeit his request will no
doubte
d
be rejected by
e Councel of state.
This was the famous S
r
Thomas Bodley, who left to the University of
Oxford
, the Public Library, which bears his name, He servd
his Country in several Ambassies, with great applause; as may
be seen in his Life, printed at Oxon 1647 quart.; and in Woods
Athenae Oxonienses Vol.1.
